title: 106_hr4258
content: The "Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2000" is also known as the "Student Loan Forgiveness for Teachers" program, which revises the loan forgiveness program for teachers under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The "Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2000" aims to encourage individuals to enter and stay in the teaching profession by repaying a portion of qualified loans for full-time teachers in public schools who are not in default on their loans. The Secretary will repay up to one-fourth of the outstanding loan obligation for each year of service over a 4-year period. The "Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2000" repays a portion of qualified loans for full-time teachers in public schools over a 4-year period. Borrowers cannot receive reductions under both this section and section 460. Loan consolidation under section 428C may qualify if used to repay specific types of loans. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations. The Secretary can issue regulations for the Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2000. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and another section. The definition of "year" for teacher service is clarified. Loan forgiveness for teachers is exempt from income tax. The Student Loan Forgiveness Act of 2000 allows for loan forgiveness for teachers, exempt from income tax. Gross income excludes loan discharge amounts under specific conditions. Effective July 1, 1998, the amendment applies to service years starting after that date. Tax credits are available for full-time public elementary and secondary school teachers under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credits of $1,000 are available for eligible full-time public elementary and secondary school teachers under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code. Eligible individuals must have been full-time teachers at a public school for the academic year ending in the taxable year. The credit is reduced by any forgiven education loans for being a teacher. Tax credits of $1,000 for full-time public elementary and secondary school teachers under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code apply to taxable years after the enactment of this Act.
